awd_titl_txt: Eco-epidemiology of Leptospirosis in Latin America:   Understanding the Dynamics of Transmission Within a Community
awd_abstract_narration: Leptospirosis, an infection of worldwide public health importance, is caused by Leptospira bacteria that can be transmitted from animals to humans. Human infection can occur after contact with infected animals or with a Leptospira-contaminated environment usually associated with agricultural practices, contamination of household or recreational water, poor housing and waste disposal, and changes in the density or proximity of infected animal (rodents, domestic animals, and wildlife). The mechanisms involved in the transmission of the bacteria and the ecological and sociological factors that affect the likelihood of human infection are poorly understood.  The objective of this project is to clarify how leptospirosis is transmitted in a community and to quantify the relative importance of the multiple sources of infection. The research team will study the ecological and sociological elements that influence human infection in rural, peri-urban and urban communities in southern Chile in order to identify effective intervention strategies for reducing the impact of leptospirosis on human health.   This research is significant because it will aid in the control of leptospirosis and other serious human infections of animal origin.  Broader impacts of this project include training of professionals in the area of emerging infectious diseases and global health, development of methodologies for studying the environmental sources of human infections, and the establishment of multinational and multidisciplinary partnerships for combating infectious diseases of global health importance.

por.por_cntn:
Leptospirosis is a zoonotic bacterial disease of worldwide distribution with varying incidence which is influenced by social and ecological conditions.  This project aimed to contribute to the understanding of the mechanisms driving the presence and transmission of Leptospira in animal hosts, the environment, and people in distinct community settings.  While seasonal and temporal effects were the major determinants of Leptospira infection in the rodent population, leptospirosis in dogs of these same communities showed notably distinct patterns by community type which were driven by the effect of dog density in urban slums vs rural communities and by rainfall. Leptospira can survive in water and soil which serve as sources of infection to human and animals. Lower household income, increased temperature, and presence of dogs were positively associated with positive puddles. Increased number of rodent signs was associated with positive puddles in the household; however, only in the lower income households.  Large-scale detection of the pathogen from environmental samples can be used for systematic environmental surveillance in order to detect changes in diversity, indicating shifts in the local epidemiology, and to identify and monitor areas of higher levels of contamination where an increased risk of human infection exists. The importance of community-level factors was also reflected in the marked differences of human prevalence of infection which were consistent with low levels of infection knowledge, risk perception, and protective practices. Through this project, we gained major insights into the complexity and the challenges of investigating the transmission dynamics of leptospirosis. Major findings revealed the ubiquity of Leptospira in non-tropical settings, and, more importantly, the locality of infection dynamics.

Broader impacts include training opportunities for students from undergrad to post-doc level through field experiences, laboratory experience, access to data, application of various methodologies, opportunities to practice communication and writing skills and to working with a team of investigators. Locally, we improved research capacity that resulted in new projects by local investigators and in improved diagnostic capabilities for human and animal leptospirosis. We have shared methods and findings internationally at scientific meetings as well as directly with governments from high-risk countries. Collaborative work developed new networks with experts in mathematical modeling, environmental sciences, and social sciences and ancillary projects investigated the epidemiology of other zoonoses co-circulating in the study communities.
